title: eth_subscribe with newPendingTransactions returns hash every 100ms on average
body:
#### System information

Erigon version: 2.28.1-dev-19f0776a

OS & Version: Debian 11

#### Expected behaviour
Return hash as soon as a new one is available.


#### Actual behaviour
Return hash on average every 100ms instead.


#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Start command for Erigon:
`./erigon/build/bin/erigon --chain=bsc --prune=hrtc --maxpeers=100 --db.pagesize=16k --datadir ~/projects/erigon_node/data/erigon --http --http.port=#### --ws --http.api=eth,debug,net,trace,web3,erigon,txpool`

Python code to subscribe to newPendingTransactions:
```
import asyncio, json, datetime
from websockets import connect

async def get_pending():
    async with connect("ws://127.0.0.1:####") as ws:
        # Subscribe
        await ws.send('{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "id": 1, "method": "eth_subscribe", "params": ["newPendingTransactions"]}')
        pending_subscription = json.loads((await ws.recv()))["result"]
        while True:
            try:

                message= json.loads(await asyncio.wait_for(ws.recv(),timeout=3))
                print(f'{datetime.datetime.now().strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f")[:-3]} - New tx with hash {message["params"]["result"]}')
            
            except Exception as e:
                print(e)

asyncio.run(get_pending())
```

#### Backtrace

The erigon node is on the same computer as the python running program.
The behaviour is the same with newPendingTransactionsWithBody.
When I tried this code with `geth` node, I don't see this behaviour, it seems that I receive hash directly.

I suspect this is because the remote transactions are processed every 100ms:
https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon-lib/blob/main/txpool/pool.go#L86

I did rebuild the image with 10ms and definitely something happened -- I got way more `pending` transactions but those included some very old ones and even validated (Ethereum mainnet).

Maybe someone from the team could explain why 100ms and if it's safe to lower this time.
I have tried querying the txpool with grpc, connecting directly via port 9094, and the contents of txpool change roughly every 100ms. The reason is probably the one ^^^.

Thank you for your replies.
I will keep this setting and adapt my code 👍
This issue is stale because it has been open for 40 days with no activity. Remove stale label or comment, or this will be closed in 7 days.
This issue was closed because it has been stalled for 7 days with no activity.
